Take EE16B. You'll love making the voice-controlled robot car in lab and be able to see how the theory comes together in practice first-hand.

---

Another vote for EE16B - it'll be required for most EE upper division courses, anyway. I've also heard good things about EE49. EECS 149 is also a solid choice, owing to the freeform final project at the end of the semester.
Take EE16B. You'll love making the voice-controlled robot car in lab and be able to see how the theory comes together in practice first-hand.

I was wondering if anyone knew of any classes on campus (EECS or otherwise) that focused on practical hardware development? For example making IoT devices for smart homes, RC cars, etc; basically stuff that involves hands-on construction, soldering, etc.

I've taken EE 16A, and though that had a lab portion (which was very guided), the class focused on homework and theory like you'd expect most (EE) classes in a university to (especially one like Berkeley) and I'd imagine upper-div EE classes have way more theory. Also, I'm not an EECS major, but I am a junior with a CS background and am currently taking upper-div CS classes (planning on majoring in DS, but that's probably an irrelevant detail).

I've extensive practical software/coding experience but I'm now trying to get into the hardware side of things, so given my preferences, I would appreciate advice. Thanks!
history.subject: Practical Hardware Classes
